Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: A Novel Human Centric CPS to Improve Motor/Cognitive Assessment and Enable Adaptive Rehabilitation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop methods and tools for a multimodal and multi-sensor assessment and rehabilitation game system called CPLAY for children with Cerebral Palsy (CP). CPLAY collects and processes multiple types of stimulation and performance data while a child is playing. Its core has a touch-screen programmable game that has various metrics to measure delay of response, score, stamina/duration, accuracy of motor/hand motion. Optional devices attached to extend CPLAY versions provide additional parallel measurements of level of concentration/participation/engagement that quantify rehabilitation activity. The approach is to model the process as a cyber-physical system (CPS) feedback loop whereby data collected from various physical 3D devices (including fNIR brain imaging) are processed into hierarchical events of low-to-high semantic meaning that impact/ adjust treatment decisions.

Intellectual Merit: The project will produce groundbreaking algorithms for event identification with a multi-level data to knowledge feedback loop approach. New machine learning, computer vision, data mining, multimodal data fusion, device integration and event-driven algorithms will lead towards a new type of cyber- physical rehabilitation science for neurological disorders. It will deliver fundamental advancements to engineering by showing how to integrate physical devices with a computationally quantitative platform for motor and cognitive skills assessment.

Broader Impacts: The project delivers a modular & expandable game system that has huge implications on the future of US healthcare and rehabilitation of chronic neurological disabilities. It brings hope to children with Cerebral Palsy via lower cost and remote rehabilitation alternatives. It brings new directions to human centered computing for intelligent decision-making that supplements evidence-based practices and addresses social and psychological isolation problems.

Motivation and objectives

The objective of this research is to develop methods and tools for a multimodal and multi-sensor assessment and rehabilitation game system called CPLAY for children with Cerebral Palsy (CP). CPLAY collects and processes multiple types of game interaction and performance data while a child is playing. The system is used both as an assessment and intervention system using various metrics including, delay of response, performance score, hand gestures and movements, level of concentration (with eye trackers and camera), participation/engagement levels, and brain activity patterns using functional near infrared (fNIR) imaging. Analysis of the collected fused data generates recommendations to support the decision making by the physical therapist (PT) and occupational therapist (OT) expert.  CPLAY has advanced backend analysis engines that detect “events” in cerebral palsy progression.

 

Summary of Activities

We developed a prototype system called CPLAY. As part of this, we developed computer games for upper limbs that model traditional occupational therapy exercises.  We integrated various types of incentives to promote user engagement and also developed interfaces to analyze and visualize the patient’s performance data. Using a cyberphysical evaluation methodology for the classification and personalization of CP systems and in collaboration with occupational therapists, we used machine learning methods to fuse the data from different sources.  We also developed new eye tracking and head motion tracking devices to measure concentration and attention as well as algorithms for point-of-gaze estimation.

Project Outcomes and Findings

We expanded the database of games to include touch screen, virtual reality, haptic and robotic games and developed a common front end to allow the therapist to decide on which is the most appropriate game for a particular CP case. We automated the data logging of the game performance, as well as the multimodal data fusion, and sensor data analysis, to help determine whether the child is ready for the next game level or a different type of game stimulus. We developed real time monitoring facilities to enable game adaptation and personalization to enable the motor, mental and psychological state of the user. Different CPLAY system versions were developed for uses at home and in the clinic.  A major finding is that for any such system to become widely used, (a) it has to be accepted by the profession of clinicians, (b) training of practitioners has to take place, and (c) the disconnect between computational innovations and the medical profession practices has to be solved.

 

Intellectual Merit

The project led to the developed of advanced computer vision and motion analysis algorithms, and gesture recognition methods. It also led to the development of speech recognition and an adaptive dialogue system.
